Questions.Question: Passphrases are ineffective passwords as they are easily guessed.
Questions.Explanation: Passphrases are effective as passwords as they are easier to type and remember, but also harder to crack than shorter passwords.

Questions.Question: Which of the following is not true about password managers?
Questions.Explanation: Password managers are typically used to store all of a user's passwords in one location. Their main purpose is not to automatically change the passwords that a user uses.

Answers.Text: They can sometimes generate passwords for users.
They are mainly used to automatically change a user's passwords.
They are mainly used to store all of a user's passwords.
None of the options.

Questions.Question: If a user's password manager is compromised their passwords are still fully protected.
Questions.Explanation: A user's passwords can be exposed if their password manager is compromised, despite this, password managers are still a far safer alternative to using the same password everywhere.

Questions.Question: Password-less systems are systems without any form of authentication at all.
Questions.Explanation: Password-less systems often include other forms of authentication, such as biometric authentication.

Questions.Question: Multi-factor authentication allows for users to:
Questions.Explanation: Multi-factor authentication is used to enforce security by making users use multiple authentication methods to verify themselves.

Answers.Text: Access a system without using a password.
Use multiple authentication methods to verify users.
Increase the speed in which authentication takes.
All of the options.

Questions.Question: Which of the following are not methods usable in multi-factor authentication?
Questions.Explanation: SMS services, QR codes and biometric authentication are all valid ways to enforce multi-factor authentication.

Answers.Text: SMS services
QR codes
Biometric authentication
None of the options.

Questions.Question: DAC is used to ensure that users do not have to multi-factor authenticate.
Questions.Explanation: DAC (Discretionary access control) is applied to decide whether a user should need multi-factor authentication. Multi-factor authentication is often needed when a new login location appears, when a significant action is being performed or when a new device is used.

Questions.Question: An administrator account can be more easily compromised if:
Questions.Explanation: An administrator account can more easily be compromised under many circumstances. Some examples include having no multi-factor authentication, using the default password or writing down passwords publicly.

Answers.Text: An employee who knows the password writes it down publicly.
No multi-factor authentication exists.
The account's password has never changed from the default.
All of the options.

Questions.Question: Credential stuffing is an attack in which leaked credentials are used against other services to access accounts.
Questions.Explanation: Credential stuffing can be used to hack into accounts, especially when users reuse passwords in multiple locations.

Questions.Question: Password cracking is:
Questions.Explanation: Password cracking is an attack in which computing power is used to guess the password that matches a user's hashed password. It is typically an offline attack that may also be time-consuming.

Answers.Text: An attack that can only be performed online.
An attack that can be performed offline.
An attack that is always achieved in a short manner of time.
An attack that is always achieved in a short manner of time, that can only be performed online.

Questions.Question: A system's credentials cannot be extracted, even if a user is currently logged into the system when it is compromised.
Questions.Explanation: An attacker can potentially extract the credentials used for a system if administrator access is granted to it while it is compromised.

Questions.Question: Password entropy is best defined as a measure of:
Questions.Explanation: Password entropy is best defined as the unpredictability of a password. A higher password entropy tends to point towards a password being harder to crack.

Answers.Text: The predictability of a password.
How commonly a password is used.
The unpredictability of a password.
The length of a password.

Questions.Question: Which of the following is true?
Questions.Explanation: DAC (Discretionary access control) is used to control the frequency in which multi-factor authentication is required. This is achieved through deciding whether a user needs to re-authenticate themselves based on certain conditions.

Answers.Text: Password hashes are used to reduce the space taken up by plaintext passwords.
Credential stuffing is a safety practice in which users change their passwords as often as they can.
DAC is typically used to reduce the frequency in which multi-factor authentication is required.
None of the options.

Questions.Question: Which is the best reason as to why GPUs are more effective at password cracking than CPUs?:
Questions.Explanation: GPUs are usually better than CPUs at password cracking as they can contain many micro-cores.

Answers.Text: CPUs are often occupied with other processes.
GPUs have many micro-cores that speed up the process.
CPUs have too many micro-cores to run the process.
None of the options.
